I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Nepal for the COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support Program (CARES Program), 
under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 pandemic response option (CPRO).1 
  
2. 
The  CARES  Program  will  help  the  government  in  implementing  its  pandemic  response 
plan—the  National  Relief  Program—to  respond  to  public  health  emergencies  and  to  mitigate 
adverse economic and social impacts caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. 
The National Relief Program, approved on 29 March 2020, includes medical and health support, 
social protection for the poor and vulnerable, economic support for affected sectors, and other 
fiscal  and  economic  measures.2 Nepal  meets  all  the  CPRO  access  criteria  (Table 1)  and  the 
detailed justifications are in Appendix 4.

The COVID-19 pandemic has caused severe sudden disruptions to the economy. It is 
projected  to  lead  to  economic  loss  of  $2.3  billion  or  7.1%  of  GDP  in  FY2020  and 
FY2021. ADB projected 6.3% GDP growth for FY2020 before the pandemic; however, 
the official GDP growth is estimated to decline to 2.3%.  With rising health and economic 
relief measures, the FY2020 fiscal deficit is projected to widen from the pre-pandemic 
estimate of 6.4% of GDP to 8.5% of GDP. ADB estimates that the economy may lose 
about 4.7% of total employment or 997,000 jobs for FY2020–FY2021.a The IMF’s May 
2020  report on  the  Rapid  Credit  Facility projects  Nepal’s  GDP  growth  to  be  1.0%  in 
FY2020 and 3.5% in FY2021.b 
On 29 March 2020, the government approved the National Relief Program, consisting 
of (i) health and medical support, (ii) social protection for the poor and vulnerable, and 
(iii)  economic  support 
for  affected  sectors.  The  government’s  countercyclical 
development expenditure program is estimated to cost about $1.26 billion for FY2020, 
of  which:  (i)  $347  million  for  health  and  medical  support,  (ii) $359 million  for  social 
protection for the poor and vulnerable, and (iii) $555 million for economic support for 
affected sectors. 
Nepal’s macroeconomic management has been generally sound with fast growth and 
benign inflation. GDP growth averaged 7.3% during FY2017–FY2019. Inflation declined 
steadily from a peak of 9.9% in FY2016 to 6.5% in the first 8 months of FY2020. The 
fiscal deficit moderated to 5.1% of GDP in FY2019, down from 6.6% in FY2018. Gross 
foreign exchange reserves were adequate at $9.5 billion at the end of FY2019, enough 
to  cover  7.8  months  of  imports,  in  FY2019.  With  an  average  revenue–GDP  ratio  of 
23.8% from FY2017 to FY2019, the revenue mobilization, excluding foreign grants, has 
been robust.

enhance public sector resilience to emergencies, especially in the health sector. MOHP

develop  detailed  institutional  mechanisms  and  interventions  to  be  adopted  during  a 
pandemic.c  The  government  also  incorporated  finance  sector  structural  reforms  to 
enable  the  regulatory  authorities  and  financial  institutions  to  maintain  the  sector’s 
liquidity and stability during emergencies.

support recovery. As growth picks up, public debt will continue to rise at a slower pace

Coronavirus  disease  and  initial  government  response.  The  first  case  of  COVID-19 
was  identified  in  Nepal  on  24  January  2020.  Since  then,  the  government  initiated  various 
containment  measures  including  procuring  essential  supplies,  equipment,  and  medicine; 
upgrading  health  infrastructure;  training  medical  personnel;  and  spreading  public  awareness. 
Other measures included prohibiting promotional activities or events, canceling on-arrival visas, 
suspending  the  issuance  of  migrant  workers’  work  permits,  suspending  school  classes  and 
examinations,  canceling  all  international  flights,  and  postponing  the  National  Assembly.  On 
24 March 2020, a nationwide lockdown came into effect. 
 
On  8  May  2020,  Nepal  had  107 confirmed  cases,  with  no  deaths  recorded.  It  has 
4. 
conducted about 15,492 swab tests and quarantined about 20,217 people. Although the number 
of  confirmed  cases  is  still  small,  Nepal  is  considered  a  high-risk  country  for  rapid  spread  of 
COVID-19 infections because of its vulnerable public health system, underdeveloped sanitation 
and  other  infrastructure,  and  densely  populated  urban  and  semi-urban  areas.  Further,  a 
substantial number of Nepali migrant workers are returning from affected countries. As of 8 May 
2020,  20,217  migrant  workers  returned  to  Nepal.  Without  urgent  and  effective  containment 
measures, Nepal’s risk of rapidly spreading the infection is high. As a landlocked country that is 
highly dependent on imports, Nepal also recognizes regional cooperation to be crucial in ensuring 
a coordinated response to mitigate the impact of the pandemic, and maintain open access and 
uninterrupted supply links. It has signed the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
(SAARC) COVID-19 response joint plan, which calls for countries in the region to work together 
to implement containment and surveillance measures. In addition, Nepal pledged $1 million to the 
SAARC COVID-19 Emergency Fund.

The plan’s objective is to prepare and strengthen the response of the health system to minimize 
the pandemic’s health impact. It presents four scenarios based on COVID-19 positive case load 
including: (i) a maximum number of positive cases under 2,000; (ii) a maximum number of positive 
cases between 2,000 and 5,000; (iii) a maximum number of positive cases between 5,000 and 
10,000; and (iv) a maximum number of positive cases greater than 10,000.4 Each of these levels 
further segregates cases into three levels of severity assuming that 80% of cases would need 
general treatment at the hospital with isolation ward and beds, 15% would need hospitalization 
with  oxygen  support  and  only  5%  would  need  intensive  care  unit  (ICU)  services.  The  plan 
prescribes strategic approaches and key interventions for (i) health systems, (ii) public health and 
social measures, (iii) curative care interventions, and (iv) strengthened management for COVID-

Nepal’s poverty is partly related to the large segment of the population who are employed 
in  the  informal  sector.  Informal  sector  employment  accounts  for  84.6%  of  total  employment.15 
Informal sector workers are not entitled to sick pay or health insurance, and are ineligible for social 
security benefits. Women are likely to be most affected, as they comprise 66.5% of informal sector 
workers  in  Nepal,  and  the  lockdown  has  increased  their  household  and  care  work.  Returnee 
migrant workers are anticipated to remain unemployed because of the pandemic’s adverse impact

against women and inhibits timely interventions to gender-based violence. Since women comprise 
70% of public sector health workers including frontline personnel, they face an unprecedented

who  support  basic  health  services  for  the  government’s  National  Relief  Program,  forming  an

Debt sustainability. Nepal’s public debt remains lower than other low-income countries 
and a net external creditor. Under the ADB baseline, the public debt to GDP ratio is projected to 
increase  over  the  projection  period  but  will  remain  below  50%  by  FY2025.  ADB’s  assessment

severe sudden disruptions in the economy. It is estimated that

travel has particularly affected Nepal’s hospitality and tourism

impact has been also visible in manufacturing industries. In the
